Eduardo, Legato has its own site - one font that certainly deserves it:   
 [http://www.xs4all.nl/~ebloem/index.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125084213/http:/www.xs4all.nl/~ebloem/index.html)   
It should have its own thread here too.   
   
The quantum leap contained in Legato is indeed somewhat "covert" - it seems highly conventional on the surface. But it's the first font (that I know of) that deliberately and intelligently breaks the domination of the Black. It's the first "notanic" typeface, where the importance of the White is given more than mere lip-service; it creates bonds in the White, hence promoting boumas. In this way it breaks the biggest barrier towards optimal text type.   
   
Which isn't to say I think it's perfect - in fact it has a serious drawback - it's a _constructed_ font. It's basically too Modernist, too regular. It needs some Fleischmann hazy magic to become divine.   
   
Plus it doesn't have serifs. :-)   
   
--

Why not? :-\>   
I appreciate you giving your best shot! It's how I learn.

![steinweiss](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125084213im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/37767.jpg)   
Design and lettering by Alex Steinweiss, 1948   
From "For the record"   
   
The incomparable Steinweiss used many pens, did plenty of embellishments in many genres, but never classical-style flourished ligatures. (So far as I can tell from my record collection and the examples in the book.) Here, he could have done the "st" lig in Kostelanetz.   
   
The style of lettering identified with him, now available as a font named "Hairspray" for some strange reason, and (shame!) unattributed (and I bet he doesn't get royalties either), is a casual, cursive, light monoline script. It was made into a font in 1939, "Steinweiss Scrawl", and available from Photolettering Inc. in the 1950s.   
   
Conclusion: the flourished joining ligatures are a product of writing with a broad-nib pen. They would be easy to do with a round-nibbed "Speedball" pen (presumably what Steinweiss used), but they don't belong ... unless the calligrapher is in a Post-modern groove.   
   
Or Pseudo-proto-modern: Storm added the ct and st ligs to Sebastian, his 18th century sans serif.

Hrant, I never implied that good design didn't matter. What I challenge is the notion that changes in typeface design can significantly improve on what we already do so well: read text. There are plenty of other reasons to design new text typefaces and to design them well, but to pretend that we're chasing some elusive readability is, as I've said before, to willfully ignore the daily reading experience of many hundreds of miliions of people reading a great diversity of writing systems under incredibly diverse and often adverse conditions. Human beings are better at reading than any improvement at the type design level can significantly affect. If you really cared about readability, you wouldn't be talking about type design at all: you'd be talking about page layout, printing and screen technologies, and other things that do have a significant impact on readability. Readability at the type design level is the base prerequisite, not an achievement.

_... random words on text make it less readable_   
   
Random words in text make it less comprehensible, but not necessarily less readable in the sense that 'readble' is commonly used on Typophile. The line between the cognitive acts of text recognition and of understanding is a porous one, and 'reading' understood in toto involves both, but the impact of random words on reading speed has to do with our ability to make sense of the text, not our ability to recognise words. In most of the discussions of readability among typographers and type designers, the comprehensive aspect is ignored, since the professional obsession is with the cognitive act of text recognition. Introducing the comprehensive aspect of reading further diminishes the relative impact of type design, since it is obvious that good writing is more important than a good typeface.

\> significantly improve   
   
And yet again I have to point out the obvious issue:   
What is "significant" in type design? Almost nothing. So it's a matter of context, and a good craftsman needs to be very concerned with the smallest of gains - they are "significant" to him, as a person creating quality objects, if for no other reason than because that justifies his existence, because it makes him happy. It is in the context of our individuality that any of this is "significant" - otherwise there are _extremely_ few really "significant" reasons to make new fonts. Plus that effort is usually better spent elsewhere anyway!   
   
Was it "significant" to use an esoteric pen to make SBL Hebrew\*? Who the hell would have noticed any difference? And then you claim "enhanced dissimilation between similar Hebrew letters", but when needed you say it doesn't matter? And then you put the top-right spur on the final-kaf anyway, even though that's exactly opposite of the claim! Only the most conservative fonts -the ones that don't worry about dissimilation- do that. I honestly don't know what to think about the aggregate of your opinions on functionality. It really seems that you're just giving people what they _expect_, depending on context. Sure, expectation is part of functionality too, but there has to be an overall rhyme and reason, at least on the personal level - otherwise it's just reactionary.   
   
\* Although when it seems necessary you tend to claim that the pen didn't influence the result...   
   
And then I have to repeat this yet again, apprently: There is a difference between what people think they can read comfortably versus what they can read comfortably for extended periods, without even realizing. It is in the latter arena that a good craftsman is most concerned. It is in the _promotion_ of efficiency, not the assumption of its irrelevance, that good design is best expressed. People don't read "fast enough" [partly] because of bad typography (and type), not because they can't read any faster. That's why using a serif font for a book matters for example. They can read sans just fine, so why not use sans for books? Because the more you push the limits of performace, the more the supposedly "insignificant" things matter.   
   
\> you'd be talking about page layout   
   
But I don't like page layout. Get it?   
   
That's like me telling you: If you're really concerned about conveying information to people (the main point of typography), then dedicate your life to the publishing and distribution of books - and websites! Or maybe you should be _writing_ book? And since conveying information to people is intended to help them, I might propose that you forget typography entirely, and concentrate on what the bulk of the human population is severly lacking and truly needs: not books, but food and decency!! Who was more significant, Claude Garamont or Rachel Corrie? Or Mother Teresa?! Who gives a crap about Garamont.   
   
But in order to propose such things I would need to ignore what _you_ need out of life - what is in _your nature_. And I will not do that - because it doesn't make sense.

I have the feeling that maybe the distinction between legibility and readability is not clear enough (or maybe I haven�t understood it well).   
For legibility I�m understanding the typographic contrast which make letters recognizable, depending on the x height, the contrast, the conventionality, etc.   
For readability I�m understanding the quality of a text by which it�s comprehensible, not having anything to do with type but with syntaxis, topic familiarity, clear ideas, etc.   
The relation between them is proportionally inverse: a readable text relies less on legibility and an unreadable text relies more on it because there is a need for extra visual information to predict and confirm the sense of the reading. I also have the notion that text recognition can be affected by unreadability due to the lack of a predictive direction on the perceptive task given by the understood sense of the text. Right?   
   
I still can�t find the fault on the sake of an improvement nor a reason to pick on someone because of it, even if it�s not considered worthy or significant or by some.

_What is "significant" in type design? Almost nothing. So it's a matter of context, and a good craftsman needs to be very concerned with the smallest of gains - they are "significant" to him, as a person creating quality objects, if for no other reason than because that justifies his existence, because it makes him happy. It is in the context of our individuality that any of this is "significant" - otherwise there are extremely few really "significant" reasons to make new fonts._   
   
This is all fine and good: if you want to justify your existence by obsessing about the miniscule significance within a miniscule significance that is improved readability at the type design level, go ahead. But it is far from clear from your typical pronouncements on this subject that this is all about 'individuality', especially when you are insulting other individuals because they don't share your obsession.   
   
_Was it "significant" to use an esoteric pen to make SBL Hebrew\*? Who the hell would have noticed any difference? And then you claim "enhanced dissimilation between similar Hebrew letters", but when needed you say it doesn't matter? And then you put the top-right spur on the final-kaf anyway, even though that's exactly opposite of the claim! Only the most conservative fonts -the ones that don't worry about dissimilation- do that._   
   
So you would prefer to confuse the final kaf with the resh rather than with the dalet? The distinguishing feature of the final kaf is its descender, which is perfectly sufficient for differentiation, especially since the letter only occurs in at the end of a word. Some typefaces model the transition from the horizontal to the vertical on the dalet (spurred) others on the resh (rounded), a few use a hybrid approach. Zvi Narkiss developed a neo-Sepharidic style that tends to favour the rounded form, and I admire his types very much, but in SBL Hebrew I decided to follow a more traditionally typographic, less cursive form. User expectation is one consideration, yes, because the users are Biblical scholars most of whom are familiar with only one or two other Hebrew typefaces (shifting from an 19th century Ashkenazic style to a Sephardic one was enough of a shock for some of them when they first saw SBL Hebrew). However, the other functional consideration -- and this is something that should be right up your street -- is that more words in the Biblical text end in resh than in dalet, therefore it seems more important to distinguish the final kaf from resh than from dalet.

\>text recognition can be affected by unreadability due to the lack of a predictive direction on the perceptive task given by the understood sense of the text. Right?   
   
Yes.   
We read best who we read most.

\> the distinction between legibility   
\> and readability is not clear enough   
   
Yes, it's confusing.   
"Legibility" has a (relatively) focused meaning, concerning the decipherability of individual glyphs; but readability is over-loaded\*, with at least three different meanings: to most poeple it refers to the textual content, as in text that's written so as to be easily understood; to most typographers it refers to the page layout, paragraph attributes like good leading, linebreaks, etc.; and the third -most esoteric and controversial, but I feel most impotant to the context of type design- meaning concerns the font itself: the way in which a font promotes decipherment of boumas - different than the decipherment of individual letters. So for example a sans is more legible but less readable than a serif font; and tight letterspacing helps readability but reduces legibility.   
   
\* Such over-loading is certainly inconvenient, but it's common, and generally context -which is always there- focuses the meaning quite well.   
   
--   
   
\> if you want to justify your existence by obsessing about ....   
   
OK, but I don't see how it's any less "significant" than what you choose to focus on. In the context of the world, they're really about the same. Does my preoccupation with reintroducing readability (in tandem with authenticity, in this case) into Armenian less significant that the way you choose to worry about what kind of pen to use for SBL Hebrew?   
   
\> it is far from clear from your typical pronouncements   
   
Yes, you have a point, and I'm slowly learning to tame my insistence that every other type designer worry [as much] about readability - it doesn't make sense. On the other hand, I think I will always get annoyed when a type designer claims that readability simply doesn't matter outright, and (to a lesser extent) when a user doesn't appreciate the difference between a designer who cares about fine-tuning readability and one who doesn't.   
   
BTW, I don't think it's "obsessive", because I know that it's just one factor - which is the reason for example that some glyphs in Patria (like the "a" and "e") have intentionally sub-optimal readability, to promote the "robust" character of the face. And like I've said before, one reason I drone on about readability is that so few other people do, and so many other people want it not to matter.   
   
\> you would prefer to confuse the final kaf with the resh rather than with the dalet?   
   
I actually don't know enough myself (what are the relative frequencies, especially wrt position?), I'm actually mostly referring to what "native" Hebrew designers (who have an innate linguistic sensitivity that we don't) are doing: it's not just one Narkiss font - the font in the Unicode table, Friedlaender's popular Hadassah of the late 50s, and every single Hebrew font in Bukvaraz\*, with the highly notable exception of the hyper-conservative Nathan, uses the "soft-corner" form.   
   
\* Even the super-blocky Atzmaut.   
   
And considering you're such a good researcher, I have to think that you knew about this general trend, but you either thought it's wrong, or you thought that in this case the spurred form makes more sense. Both could be valid, but the second one simply doesn't jibe with dissimilitude (as far as I can tell), which in turn doesn't jibe with what you've said in this thread!   
   
\> The distinguishing feature of the final kaf is its descender   
   
But the descender space is so weak in Hebrew - it doesn't seem safe to rely on it. But it depends -again- on the difference between legibility and readability. Sure, when you give a person many seconds to decide what a glyph is, there's no problem - there almost never is. But there are much more severe requirements of decipherability during high-speed immersive reading. Just like how an "rn" can be read as an "m" in English text - but only during immersion. And this is also why typos go unnoticed so frequently.   
   
\> I decided to follow a more traditionally typographic, less cursive form.   
   
Right. And my point is that to me it seems to have been at the expense of the "dissimilitude" that you claim. My impression is that this conservatism was the deciding factor, irrespective of dissimilitude, linguistics, etc.   
   
But really, what I mind most isn't that you're conservative, it isn't that you claim "dissimilitide", and it isn't that you're saying it doesn't matter anyway - it's the confluence of all three! :-/   
   
BTW, I'm really not trying to discredit you in toto, I just want to point out what I see as the flaw in the aggregate opinion/action.   
   
\> more words in the Biblical text end in resh than in dalet   
   
Yes, this would be significant - and it would be quite a nice refinement - as well as an endorsement for linguistic analysis! Is the data available?   
   
And a question: So is it the opposite in general Hebrew text?   
   
hhp

BTW, there's nothing 'esoteric' about a Pilot parallel pen, Hrant.   
I got myself one, a couple of months ago, and I like it. I still think it's a limited tool (I'd say it's too 'mechanical', maybe I should now try other kinds of pen), but it's a good way to start understanding the particularities (pros and cons) of calligraphy.   
Get yourself one too. ;-)

\> there's nothing 'esoteric' about a Pilot parallel pen   
   
Not to us, sure. But I have to think that the main appeal to laymen -those who even care- is in the "ooh-aah factor", without really getting -or even caring to get- the funky nuances we seem to worry about so much.   
   
Anyway, my point is that relying on a particular writing instrument to make a font is no less esoteric than worrying about readability.   
   
hhp

_Yes, this would be significant - and it would be quite a nice refinement - as well as an endorsement for linguistic analysis! Is the data available?_   
   
I can probably get a count of word terminal letters. Give me a couple of days.   
   
_And a question: So is it the opposite in general Hebrew text?_    
   
Probably. However, modern Hebrew distinguishes tense in a regular way, and I don't how this is done or what impact it might have on word endings.   
   
   
I don't rely on writing instruments to make any font. In the case of SBL Hebrew, _unusually_, I began the design process by making letters with a broadnib. This wasn't designing per se, this was research on how the steep ductus of Middle Eastern scripts affects the contrast pattern of individual letters in specific writing styles. As I explained during my ATypI presentation on the subject, I think it is important to understand a script within a cultural and historical context, and the best way to understand a script is to write it as it has been written. It happened, at the time, that I didn't have a broadnib pen with the properly angled nib, so I just used a typical broadbnib calligraphy pen. For the next time I want to write Hebrew or Arabic, I now have a set of properly cut reed pens.   
   
I'm troubled that you seem to have conflated this initial research and sketching with designing the typeface, and in some determinative way. As I've explained several times in the past, I design my types entirely onscreen. If I sketch on paper, with outlines, shading, a nib, or any other method, it is only to explore ideas about form. I suppose there might be someone out there who could actually produce the forms of SBL Hebrew, with their various non-chirographic adjustments of weight and terminal, with a broadnib pen. I couldn't.   
   
_Anyway, my point is that relying on a particular writing instrument to make a font is no less esoteric than worrying about readability._    
   
Indeed, and there is nothing wrong with esoterica, especially not in this business. But there would be something wrong with demanding that all other type designers should use this particular tool, and insulting them if they don't.

\> I can probably get a count of word terminal letters.   
   
I thought you had that already? Anyway, it would indeed be great to see the stats - thanks.   
   
\> .... it is only to explore ideas about form.   
   
While I explore ideas about form by _doubting_ established practice.   
To each his own, and of course we have to let others decide which approach is good for what.   
   
\> there would be something wrong with demanding   
\> that all other type designers should use this   
\> particular tool, and insulting them if they don't.   
   
I didn't insult you for using any particular tool. I might even claim that you "insulted" me for using _my_ "esoteric" tool: an understanding of readability. My complaint here -and it remains- is that the triple whammy of: an esoteric marking method, a claim of dissimilation, and a dismissal of the relevance of [font] readability, is non-sensical.   
   
hhp
